descriptions.title: An Overview of the Term Frisbee and Its Translations
descriptions.content:
Although the term "Frisbee" is technically a registered trademark of the Wham-O toy company, it is used more popularly than the proper term, "flying disc."  In fact, the term "flying disc" is rarely used, if ever, often abbreviated to just "disc."  Frisbees can be used in a variety of settings, from recreational throwing, to Frisbee golf, to Ultimate Frisbee.

The Chinese term, "fei pan," literally means "flying plate," "flying dish," or "flying disc" ("pan" is a relatively diverse term in Chinese).  The pronunciation of the word "fei pan" is not too far from the English term "Frisbee," making it an attractive translation.

The Tibetan term, "phur sder," taken from Khenpo Tsültrim Lodrö's Tibetan-Chinese-English Dictionary of Modern Vocabulary, is a direct calque of the Chinese "fei pan," but the attractive pronounciation and, I would argue, even the meaning of the word is skewed.  When "fei pan" becomes "phur sder," we no longer have a flying disc, but merely a "flying plate."  Therefore, in the vein of the Tibetan translation for airplane, "gnam grus" (literally, sky boat; not a calque of the Chinese term "fei ji," flying machine), I have provided an alternative term, "nam 'khor" (sky disc) which, I think, is a much more accurate and appropriate translation.
